In a quiet house at Number Seventeen, One Thousandth street, iarlynburg, (a sub- urb of New-York,) the drowsy afternoon crept past before the eves of a benign-look- ing middle-aged lady, in spectacles, and with her needlework before her; Mrs. Gentry. The pussy-cat dozed in the corner, the ca- nary slept on its perch, and the dog lay basking in the broad path of sun upon the yellow carpet. Mrs. Gentry's needlework slipped silently to the floor, her eyes closed, and she slept. And -the brawny Ellen snored in accordance mnthe kitchen; and the clock ticked drowsily on the whitewashed wall; and all was som- nolence and silence. Mr. Gentry, tapping away with his little hammer at his little watch-springs and trin- kets of tiny brass, with his crutches erect against the work-bench gravely looking on, in the little back-room up-stairs, was hardly noisier than the clock. There came a click, as of a key turning in a lock, followed immediately by the signal lang ! of a heavy street-door. The Prince had arrived to blow the bugle-horn and wake the inmates of the enchanted castle. Mrs. Gentry started to her feet ; the pussy-cat mewed lustily, and the dog barked and wag- ged his tail with delight ; and the brawny Ellen ceased snoring, and smiled, and put the tea-kettle on. The canary jumped off its perch and chirped merrily, and the clock fell to ringing its five o'clock bell, and all was joy-
ful noise and activity in the house - for Willie Gentry had come home. Ile was a noble-looking youth, with broad shoulders, well thrown back, and a head which lie carried with the ails of a king. His hair clustered in thick masses of soft, dark brown, much the same as his mother's had been he- fore time had increased the value of hers by showering silver there. His hazel eyes were playful and vivacious in expression.
